p: We prove this formula using the so-called inclusion-exclusion principle in Supplementary Note 1. In the modified BMA the probability densities of future metric A given all model pairs are subtracted, weighted by the respective pair probabilities; conditional weighted densities given model triplets are added back again, and so forth. As Eq. ( 4) shows, the full law considers potential model dependencies up to order n. We propose to adopt a new term “model non-exclusivity”, which refers to the fact that more than one model can be jointly consistent with reality. Non-exclusive model probabilities incorporate both models’ skill at capturing observations, as well as inter-model dependencies (Eq. ( 4)).
